title.value: Implementing a Hierarchical Deep Learning Approach for Simulating multilevel Auction Data
title.justification: The title is explicitly stated at the beginning of the paper, indicating the deep learning approach for auction data simulation.
title.quote: Implementing a Hierarchical Deep Learning Approach for Simulating multilevel Auction Data

extractions.description: The paper presents a deep learning methodology combining deep generative modeling with a bid prediction learner, designed to simulate realistic synthetic first-price auction data. This method addresses the challenges of high-cardinality discrete feature spaces and multilevel structures in auction data.

type.justification: The paper discusses the implementation and validation of deep learning models for generating synthetic auction data, indicating it is empirical research.
type.quote: Our methodology combines deep generative modeling (DGM) with an artificial learner that predicts the conditional bid distribution based on auction characteristics, contributing to advancements in simulation-based research.

name.value: Simulation of auction data using Deep Learning
name.justification: The paper's main focus is the simulation of auction data using deep learning models, specifically deep generative models.
name.quote: We present a deep learning solution to address the challenges of simulating realistic synthetic first-price sealed-bid auction data.

name.justification: Deep generative models such as GANs and VAEs are central to the paper's methodology for auction data simulation.
name.quote: The method developed in this paper utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12].

name.justification: The study applies deep learning to economic models and auction data, indicating a focus on economic applications.
name.quote: This approach lays the groundwork for creating realistic auction environments suitable for agent-based learning and modeling applications.

name.justification: Generative adversarial networks are discussed as a core component for auction data generation.
name.quote: The method developed in this paper utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11].

is_contributed.justification: GANs are existing models utilized in the study for data simulation but not contributed by the study itself.
is_contributed.quote: utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12] for the replication of the auction feature space.

is_executed.justification: The paper involves training and testing the GAN model, indicating execution.
is_executed.quote: The method developed in this paper utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12] for the replication of the auction feature space.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the effectiveness of GANs with VAEs for data generation based on inception scores.
is_compared.quote: The CTGAN’s ability to generate data according to hand-crafted conditional vectors made it particularly suitable for simulating auction scenarios in our study.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper specifically mentions it uses GANs based on the original model by Goodfellow et al.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12].

name.justification: Variational autoencoders are utilized for auction feature space replication.
name.quote: utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12] for the replication of the auction feature space.

is_contributed.justification: VAEs are existing models utilized in the study for data simulation but not contributed by the study itself.
is_contributed.quote: utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12] for the replication of the auction feature space.

is_executed.justification: The paper involves training and testing the VAE model, indicating execution.
is_executed.quote: The method developed in this paper utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12] for the replication of the auction feature space.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the effectiveness of VAEs with GANs for data generation based on inception scores.
is_compared.quote: evaluation metrics for the three classifiers when trained on synthetic examples generated by the GAN-based and VAE-based methods are reported.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper specifically mentions it uses VAEs as per the original paper by Kingma et al.
referenced_paper_title.quote: utilizes generative adversarial networks (GANs) [11] and variational autoencoders (VAEs) [12].

name.justification: CTGAN is identified in the paper as a particularly effective model for the task.
name.quote: The CTGAN’s ability to generate data according to hand-crafted conditional vectors made it particularly suitable for simulating auction scenarios in our study.

is_contributed.justification: CTGAN is not introduced by this paper but utilized within its proposed methodology.
is_contributed.quote: Recent advancements in deep generative modeling (DGM), such as the development of the conditional tabular generative adversarial networks (CTGANs) [13], have enabled the efficient handling of high-cardinality discrete distributions.

is_executed.justification: CTGAN is actively employed for data generation in the study.
is_executed.quote: The CTGAN’s ability to generate data according to hand-crafted conditional vectors made it particularly suitable for simulating auction scenarios in our study.

is_compared.justification: The CTGAN's effectiveness is explicitly compared against that of VAEs for generating auction data.
is_compared.quote: Our results demonstrated that while both GANs and VAEs are capable of generating realistic artificial data, the CTGAN outperformed the tabular VAE in our context.

referenced_paper_title.value: Modeling Tabular data using Conditional GAN
referenced_paper_title.justification: The CTGAN model is based on the work by Xu et al. as cited in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Recent advancements in deep generative modeling (DGM), such as the development of the conditional tabular generative adversarial networks (CTGANs) [13], have enabled the efficient handling of high-cardinality discrete distributions.

name.justification: BidNet is introduced as a model specifically designed to predict bid distributions based on auction features.
name.quote: Additionally, our Bidnet architecture is specifically designed to address the multilevel issue inherent to auction data.

is_contributed.justification: BidNet is a novel model contribution by this paper specifically for the auction data generation context.
is_contributed.quote: Additionally, our Bidnet architecture is specifically designed to address the multilevel issue inherent to auction data.

is_executed.justification: BidNet is trained and its performance validated using real-world and synthetic data.
is_executed.quote: This section evaluates the faithfulness of the synthetic auction features and the performance of BidNet in generating synthetic bids.

is_compared.justification: BidNet's performance is compared against baseline models like regression trees and MSVR.
is_compared.quote: BidNet is, on average, the best model. Note that both the MSVR (Multi-output Support Vector Regression) and the regression tree do not inherit the topological flexibility of a neural network, such as BidNet.

referenced_paper_title.justification: BidNet is introduced as a new model in this paper, thus no reference paper title is applicable.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Additionally, our Bidnet architecture is specifically designed to address the multilevel issue inherent to auction data.

name.justification: SEAO dataset is a public procurement dataset from Quebec used extensively in the paper for auction data simulation.
name.quote: We have chosen the context of public procurement to demonstrate our ability to simulate realistic first-price auctions effectively. To this end, we rely on the data provided by the "Système électronique d’appel d’offre" (SEAO)

referenced_paper_title.justification: The SEAO dataset is used as part of the empirical work in the paper, and is not specifically attributed to a separate reference paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We have chosen the context of public procurement to demonstrate our ability to simulate realistic first-price auctions effectively. To this end, we rely on the data provided by the "Système électronique d’appel d’offre" (SEAO).

name.justification: Mentioned briefly in the paper as an example where DGM methods are applied, not directly used in this study.
name.quote: DGMs have emerged as a powerful tool for addressing low degrees of freedom. Specifically, DGMs amplify observations and enhance weak signals within categorical configurations, enabling the generation of synthetic data that closely approximates the characteristics of real-world data. This technology has found applications in a diverse range of domains, such as credit card datasets.

referenced_paper_title.value: Improving Detection of Credit Card Fraudulent Transactions using Generative Adversarial Networks
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the application of DGMs in credit card datasets is cited, indicating an external reference for this dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Improving Detection of Credit Card Fraudulent Transactions using Generative Adversarial Networks [23]

name.justification: Similar to credit card datasets, medical records are mentioned as an application domain but not used in this paper.
name.quote: Additionally, DGMs have been shown to benefit privacy-sensitive applications involving medical or financial data, leading to specialized literature in this area [28].

referenced_paper_title.value: Extending a Generative Adversarial Network to Produce Medical Records with Demographic Characteristics and Health System Use

name.justification: Mentioned in passing as an example of applications of DGM, not actually used in the research of this paper.
name.quote: For example, DGM-based travel behavior simulations have employed restricted Boltzmann machines [29], while GAN-based financial correlation matrices and time-series sampling have been used for simulating financial systems [16, 30].

name.justification: References the use of auction data in internet advertising economic context, not directly used here.
name.quote: The study of first-price auctions, in particular, is crucial for understanding the mechanisms and dynamics that govern their functioning, which are prevalent in numerous industries and applications, including online advertising [2], electricity markets [3], and public procurement in general [4].

referenced_paper_title.value: Internet Advertising and the Generalized Second-Price Auction: Selling Billions of Dollars Worth of Keywords
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference paper discusses auction data applicable to internet advertising.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Internet Advertising and the Generalized Second-Price Auction: Selling Billions of Dollars Worth of Keywords [2].

name.justification: The paper mentions using the Python 'xml' library to process XML format data.
name.quote: Data for each year, and in some cases each month, must be fetched separately. The raw data, provided in XML format, needs conversion into a workable tabular array. We utilized the Python "xml" library to convert and save the data in pickle (.pkl) format.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Standard library usage does not warrant a reference paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We utilized the Python "xml" library to convert and save the data in pickle (.pkl) format.
